update.description:
depends on sdformat [pull request #671](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/671/add-transparency-to-visual-dom/diff)

Setting a <visual>'s <transparency> in sdf should now work.

Here’s an example of setting the visual transparency of a simple shape and a mesh:

![](https://bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/508375828-visual_transparency.png)
‌
update.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

content.raw:
This is introducing a compiler warning:

`Condition '_visual.Geom()->Type()==sdf::GeometryType::MESH' is always true`

That's because of the `else if (_visual.Geom()->Type() != sdf::GeometryType::MESH)` above.
content.html:
This is introducing a compiler warning:

Condition '_visual.Geom()->Type()==sdf::GeometryType::MESH' is always true

That's because of the else if (_visual.Geom()->Type() != sdf::GeometryType::MESH) above.

hmm that worked for me. I tested with simple shapes. Just checking, do you have latest ign-rendering2 branch with [these changes](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/247/backport-transparency-setting-based-on/diff)?

The second one shows up fully transparent, which is expected because <transparency> is set to 1 \(opposite of opaque\)

‌

pull_request.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

pullrequest.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

content.raw:
While reviewing this, I noticed that the alpha value from `<material>` is not having an effect. Was I wrong to expect these 2 to be equivalent?

```
           <transparency>0.5</transparency>
           <material>
              <ambient>0 0 1 1</ambient>
              <diffuse>0 0 1 1</diffuse>
              <specular>0 0 1 1</specular>
            </material>
```
and

```
           <transparency>1</transparency>
           <material>
              <ambient>0 0 1 0.5</ambient>
              <diffuse>0 0 1 0.5</diffuse>
              <specular>0 0 1 0.5</specular>
            </material>
```

The 2nd is just showing up opaque.
content.html:
While reviewing this, I noticed that the alpha value from <material> is not having an effect. Was I wrong to expect these 2 to be equivalent?

           <transparency>0.5</transparency>
           <material>
              <ambient>0 0 1 1</ambient>
              <diffuse>0 0 1 1</diffuse>
              <specular>0 0 1 1</specular>
            </material>

and

           <transparency>1</transparency>
           <material>
              <ambient>0 0 1 0.5</ambient>
              <diffuse>0 0 1 0.5</diffuse>
              <specular>0 0 1 0.5</specular>
            </material>

The 2nd is just showing up opaque.

content.raw:
I had a chance to play with it with the Cafe model \(chosen since it’s quite a complex one\) and observed some visual glitches.  
I suspect it’s just an ign-rendering issue though, so this lgtm.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2703361158-sdf_transparency_glitches_short.gif)
My recording software is not that great, but you can see an object disappearing after the first window and the walls becoming white after the second.
content.html:
I had a chance to play with it with the Cafe model (chosen since it’s quite a complex one) and observed some visual glitches.
I suspect it’s just an ign-rendering issue though, so this lgtm.

My recording software is not that great, but you can see an object disappearing after the first window and the walls becoming white after the second.

pullrequest.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

content.raw: +1 for using the product of transparencies. This is what I'm used to in other application where adjusting a transparency at one level of a hierarchy multiplies with transparencies in lower levels of the hierarchy instead of overriding all of them with the transparency values of the parent object.
content.html: +1 for using the product of transparencies. This is what I'm used to in other application where adjusting a transparency at one level of a hierarchy multiplies with transparencies in lower levels of the hierarchy instead of overriding all of them with the transparency values of the parent object.

pull_request.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

pullrequest.title: Add support for setting visual transparency through SDF

content.raw:
Just a clarification on the behavior, I understand that the <transparency> tag will override whatever was specified in the mesh materials and from what I see this is coherent with what gazebo used to do, which is great for porting.  
The alternative behavior would be doing a product of the transparencies, which is similar to what is done in collada with the <transparency> and <transparent> tag.

I can think of at least one “edge case” in which overriding the transparency of every submesh instead of multiplying would be counterintuitive.  
Let’s say we have a mesh with both fully opaque and partially transparent submeshes \(i.e. a building with windows, such as [cafe](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Cafe)\). Now if we write any transparency tag in sdf it will override all the submeshes, which means we will lose “relative” transparency between walls and windows.  
This wouldn’t happen if we multiply the values, which means that we would end up with the whole model being “more transparent” but the relative transparency between windows and walls will be kept.

I can see pros and cons to both approaches \(consistency with gazebo / more “accurate” rendering\), what do you think?
content.html:
Just a clarification on the behavior, I understand that the <transparency> tag will override whatever was specified in the mesh materials and from what I see this is coherent with what gazebo used to do, which is great for porting.
The alternative behavior would be doing a product of the transparencies, which is similar to what is done in collada with the <transparency> and <transparent> tag.

I can think of at least one “edge case” in which overriding the transparency of every submesh instead of multiplying would be counterintuitive.
Let’s say we have a mesh with both fully opaque and partially transparent submeshes (i.e. a building with windows, such as cafe). Now if we write any transparency tag in sdf it will override all the submeshes, which means we will lose “relative” transparency between walls and windows.
This wouldn’t happen if we multiply the values, which means that we would end up with the whole model being “more transparent” but the relative transparency between windows and walls will be kept.

I can see pros and cons to both approaches (consistency with gazebo / more “accurate” rendering), what do you think?
